valItem.gloss: with type="artist": Designate type of painter as appropriate in the note element.
with type="artist": this includes printmaking for books.
with type="artist": this includes engravings for books.
with type="artist". for designers of buildings.
with type="artist". for designers and planners of gardens. The occupation of gardener, for one who helps maintain a garden, goes with @type="service"
with type="artist". This includes book illustrators.
with type="bookProducer". Do not use for art printing. For that, use one of the subtypes associated with type="artist".
with type="religious". Use for Catholic clergy as well as Greek/Roman clergy. Synonymous with priestess for the purposes of our encoding.
with type="religious". For composers of religious music.
with type="religious". For musical performers in church settings and religious contexts.
with type="religious". For non-leadership roles serving the church (such as pew-opener, sexton, or verger).
with type="educator". For public lecturers on educational topics.
with type="scholar". Distinct from natural philosopher.
with type="scholar". Covers the natural sciences and earth sciences, and includes biologist, botanist, ornithologist, geologist, etc.
with type="scholar". for antiquarian collectors and those working in libraries and museums.
with type="scholar". For those who research artifacts rather than collect them.
with type="scholar". For those who study agriculture.
For a powerful person who researches the supernatural or the spirit world, for example, Prospero or Dr. Faustus. With type="scholar".
with type="explorer". Commands a ship, distinct from military post.
with type="legal". British lawyers who can plead in court.
with type="legal". British lawyers who do not plead in court.
with type="legal". ONLY appropriate if law practitioner from the United States.
with type="legal". ex: Mr. Justice Talfourd
with type="legal". For constable, police, or sheriff, those involved in law enforcement.
with type="literary". For essayists who are not primarily writing specific literary/art reviews, but more broad-ranging philosophical or aesthetic writings.
with type="literary". For literary, theatre / art critics and reviewers.
with type="literary". For those who systemically study languages, not simply translators.
with type="theater". General term for all sexes; do not use "actress".
with type="theater". Includes opera singers in performing roles.
with type="theater". For actor-managers and theater managers like William Macready.
with type="theater". For production designers, costume-makers, makers of stage sets and props.
with type="theater". For pit players of music supporting the stage.
with type="theater". For writers of instrumental and vocal music for the stage, including lyricists and librettists.
with type="medical". Includes barbers and others who do surgery and bloodletting.
with type="medical". Includes, should we ever see one, a "man-midwife" or a male who assists with births and is not a physician or surgeon.
with type="benefactor". For doers of benevolent activities outside of the arts
with type="benefactor". For supporters of the arts, theatre, and writers
with type="benefactor". For individual benevolent activities involving labor rather than money
with type="government". Titles like King, Queen, Princess are coded in <roleName>, not <occupation>.

with type="government". Use for elected officials and those running for election or who are in office by reason of political party or affiliation. Code their official title (such as "Member of Parliament for Westminster) with <roleName>.
with type="government". For political or reformist orators who are not clergy, actors, or prophets.
with type="government". Any public advocate for political or social reform.
with type="government". For aristocracy and others whose job is to serve at court in some capacity.
with type="government". Ambassadors and other diplomatists. Roles like “Ambassador to the Court of St. James” are coded in <roleName>.
with type="government". For management positions, high-ranking civil service positions within the British empire, etc. Lower-ranking positions should be coded as subtype="clerk".
with type="government". For postal service occupations.
Appointed by Parliament or employed, for example, by a local government committee to survey roads or parks. With type="government".
For male servants involved in tending the house; includes page. with type="service".
with type="service": Use for one who tends a garden. If raising money from the garden, use instead type="trade" subtype="farmer".
For a personal nurse attendant as member of a household. With type="service".
For the head servant who can speak and act on behalf of the household owners. With type="service".
For male servants involved in tending the house; includes page. with type="service".
with type="service": Use for one who tends a garden. If raising money from the garden, use instead type="trade" subtype="farmer".
For a personal nurse attendant as member of a household. With type="service".
For the head servant who can speak and act on behalf of the household owners. With type="service".
Includes specialist work related to footgear, including patten makers, clog makers, and bootmakers. With type="trade".
with type="trade". For a retailer of beer/wine.
with type="trade". For an employee in a shop.
Includes collar makers, those preparing garments for men. (For makers of women’s clothing use seamstress.) With type="trade".
Cuts, installs, and removes glass from windows and doors. With type="trade".
Broadly applicable to stage coach drivers, hired drivers, or those carrying chair lifts. With type="trade".
For those employed in hunting activities (like trapping hares) as well as those trading in items involved with hunting. With type="trade".
For street magicians, illusionists, fortune tellers, those making a living in magic arts. With type="trade".

occupation.roleName: Assistant Professor of English Missouri Southern State University
